title: Police pin African-American girl, 13, to ground as she struggles in 'disturbing' video
text:

A city mayor has called a video of three police officers pinning a 13-year-old African-American girl to the ground 'deeply disturbing to watch'.

The video shows a male police officer place his leg on the girl's head as she struggles on the floor of a shop.

His colleague appears to places his leg on her back as she kicks her legs while a witness remonstrates with the officers, shouting: "She's throwing up guys."

The footage was filmed in a UPS Store in Saint Paul, in the Midwestern state of Minnesota and has sparked a backlash.

Mayor of Saint Paul, Melvin Carter, has ordered an investigation.

He said: "This video is deeply disturbing to watch.

"I have asked Chief Axtell to launch a formal Internal Affairs investigation into the circumstances surrounding this arrest as soon as possible."

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

The video was recorded by Helen Willman, who works at the store and posted it on Facebook on Friday.

Police spokesman Steve Linders told media that he understood members of the public would find it difficult to watch the arrest of someone "who's physically resisting" but that the girl was banned from the area until August 2020 "because she has been a chronic problem at that location."

He added: “It’s unfortunate that she ran from the officer, resisted arrest and that she continues to go back to the BP gas station where there have been … robberies and a murder.

“We are hopeful that this problem can be rectified through the criminal justice system.”

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

Nekima Levy Armstrong, a local civil rights lawyer, said: “This is absolutely disgusting treatment of a black girl at the hands of two white male St. Paul police officers.

"Why was all of this manhandling of a young girl necessary? This child is not property. I am appalled.”

She later hailed the police investigation, saying: "Friends, This is an example of what happens when we speak up, when we record incidents of police abuse, and when we demand justice.

"This is a good starting point for disrupting business as usual. Thanks to Helen Dillman for recording the incident and documenting what she witnessed."

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

Police said police had tried to stop the girl at a Midway BP station earlier in the day, an area identified as a crime hotspot.

They say she violated a no-trespassing order and ran from police.

And in the struggle later, the officers claim she scratched and punched one of them in the head.

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

In a press conference on Thursday, the young girl's mum, Davida Conover, claimed her daughter has mental health problems and the officers have had several previous encounters with her and were too aggressive on this occassion.

“She was basically treated like an animal,” she said.

Officers Alexander Graham, Grady Sheehy and Charles Busch are each the subject of an internal affairs investigation, the Star Tribune reports.

St. Paul Police Federation President Paul Kuntz said: “I think they used the minimal amount of force that they possibly could to get her under control.

“There were no punches. Nothing of that nature.”
description: The footage, taken in a UPS store in Saint Paul, Minnesota, has sparked an investigation into three police officers who apprehended the teenager
